fields.description:
A cooperation between the KU Leuven and the University of Vienna, directed by Michael Jursa and Kathleen Abraham.

NABUCCO began through the initiative of Kathleen Abraham at the KU Leuven with the collaboration of Michael Jursa at the University of Vienna. NABUCCO's primary aim is to make cuneiform documentary sources originating from Babylonia and dated to the Age of Empires (c. 770 BCE – 75 CE) accessible through metadata and paraphrases or 'digests' that cover the documents' contents, prosopography, and archival background. Data have been provided, in addition to the persons mentioned above, by Stefania Ermidoro, Melanie Gross, Evelien Vanderstraeten, Matthias Adelhofer and others, and over the years NABUCCO has benefited significantly from the input, intellectual and technical, of Shai Gordin. The creation of the site in its present form and location, hosted by the Austrian Academy of Science's ACDH, was largely the work of Reinhard Pirngruber. Funding has come, in different phases, from the KU Leuven, the Belgian Science Policy Office (Project PVII/14), the University of Vienna, and the Austrian Science Fund (FWF, Vienna; most recently project I 3927).
fields.subtitle: Neo Babylonian Cuneiform Corpus Project
fields.title: Nabucco

fields.description:
This WP will be conducted by the Jena project part. Using the collective biography of the Eanna scribes as a starting point for the
investigation into their work and the Files they produced (see WP 7), WP 6 will create a prosopography of this well-defined and well documented group of individuals. The prosopography will go beyond a mere update of Kümmel’s now outdated prosopographic study of the Eanna scribes (Kümmel 1979), while Bongenaar 1997, the most comprehensive prosopographic study on the temple community of Ebabbar, will serve as a useful guideline for the analysis of the Eanna material.
fields.title: A Prosopography of the Eanna scribes and social network analysis

fields.description:
The protagonist of this archive, or rather this property file, is Mušēzib-Marduk/Kiribtu/Sîn-nāṣir (6 Esarhaddon-­15 Kandalānu). It consists of thirty-two tablets (twenty-six unique texts) mostly in London, with strays at Yale, in Paris, Geneva, Philadelphia (Free Library) and even among the UET 4 material. The majority of the texts are title deeds for acquired real estate, and most of the promissory notes concern real estate.

Mušēzib-Marduk owned or acquired several urban properties in Babylon and even more in Uruk; he also invested substantial amounts of money in orchards within or in the vicinity of Uruk.
fields.name: Sîn-nāṣir

fields.author: Johannes Hackl, Michael Jursa, Małgorzata Sandowicz, with contributions by Matthias Adelhofer
fields.description:
Involved Persons

Hackl, Johannes (PI); Jursa, Michael (PI); Sandowicz, Malgorzata (PI); Lassen, Agnete (Cooperation Partner); Waerzeggers, Caroline (Cooperation Partner); Agut, Damien (Cooperation Partner); Mühl, Simone (Cooperation Partner); Lämmerhirt, Kai (Cooperation Partner); Jiménez, Enrique (Cooperation Partner); Helwing, Barbara (Cooperation Partner)

Abstract

The Babylonian cuneiform tablets conventionally labeled as the ‘Eanna temple archive’ represent one of the most important text groups from Ancient Babylonia, and they are arguably the most multifaceted collection of archival material from the best documented period of Babylonian history, the long sixth century. Counterintuitively, and numerous preceding studies (including several by the project coordinators) notwithstanding, no truly comprehensive investigation of these texts as a body of documentary data, as an ‘archive’, has ever been attempted. DigEanna will close this knowledge gap. Building on and extending the predecessor project NaBuCCo, DigEanna will make available the data and new insights as they are gained in this on-line database.
fields.subtitle: A Digitalization of the Eanna Archive
fields.title: DigEanna

fields.description: perhaps not all such texts are (originally?) from Eanna

A study will be carried out on the topography of Eanna, which will pursue the methodological approach pioneered by Falkenstein (1941) and developed by Beaulieu (2003: 29–34). Keywords of the Eanna database digests will serve as focus points of this study, whose objective will be to identify and ideally locate temple parts (gates and courtyards), cultic structures (minor temples, chapels, daises), as well as workshops, storerooms, and small installations (such as the cashboxes). By linking topographic points and zones with functionaries and their activities, the study will attempt to delineate the levels of access within Eanna and areas in which guards, oblates, and priests operated. The line of research linking groups of texts with areas of activities has already proven effective in identifying functions of buildings and possible findspots of tablets within Eanna (Kleber 2021).
fields.title: The temple and its topographical footprint in the city

fields.description: This work package focuses on texts written in the time span between the final years of Assyrian rule over Babylonia and the mid-reign of Nebuchadnezzar. Tasks will be assembling the Files, reconstructing the pertinent Dossiers and Bureaus and investigating the hypothesis that there occurred in fact a break in archival continuity around Nebuchadnezzar’s 20th year that warrants the distinction between the Early and the Late Eanna Archive. We will also try and substantiate the causality underlying the archival break (following the hypothesis setout in Jursa and Gordin 2018). For this pupose, a prosopographically-oriented MA thesis on temple personnel working outside the city during the period covered by the Early Eanna Archive will be written
fields.title: Dossiers in the Early Eanna Archive

fields.description:
The “dead” temple archive of Eanna consists of about 8,000 published and unpublished texts mostly acquired on the antiquities market in the early twentieth century and now housed in major museums and collections in the US (Yale, Princeton) and Europe (Paris, Berlin, London). In addition, there are thousands of tablets and (predominantly) fragments found by the German excavations. The archive contains some material from the time of the Assyrian domination, but dense information is only available from the beginning of the reign of Nabopolassar. There is a clear break in the second year of Darius, possibly connected to the investigations into the affairs of the corrupt temple slave Gimillu; only comparatively few later texts are known. The latest texts dates to 29 Dar.

The high percentage of contracts found in the Eanna archive (vis-à-vis Ebabbar/Sippar), at least in the collections, originating from illicit excavations, is striking. What this means for the structure of the archive remains to be investigated. Another clear distinction is the fact that only few and comparatively small private archives could be identified in the material originating from the clandestine excavations.
fields.name: Eanna temple

fields.description:
This is the largest private archive from first millennium Babylonia spanning five generations with ca. 1,700 identified tablets and reports (by illicit excavators) speak of well above 2,000 texts. The majority of the tablets is in the British museum, in the 1876-11-17 collection and others; comparatively smaller groups are in the Louvre, Bibliothèque Nationale, Metropolitan Museum, J.P. Morgan Library, Ashmolean Museum, Pitt Rivers Museum, Royal Scottisch Museum, Museo di Storia ed Arte, Finnisches Nationalmuseum, Birmingham Museums and Art Gallery, Universitätsbibliothek Giessen, Oriental Institute Chicago, Fitzwilliam Museum, University of British Columbia, Musées Royaux, J.F. Lewis Collection, Freie Universität Berlin, Harvard Semitic Museum, Princeton Theological Seminary, Free Library of Philadelphia, and private collections. The main protagonists are all offspring of a single male line: Šulāya/Nabû-zēru-ukīn/Egibi (20 Npl­-23 Nbk), Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya (15 Nbk-­12 Nbn), Itti-Marduk-balāṭu (= Iddināya)/Nabû-ahhē-iddin (5 Nbn­-8 Cam), Marduk-nāṣir-apli (= Širku)/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu (1-­35 Dar) and finally his son Nidinti-Bēl (32 Dar­-0 Šamaš-erība). Itti-Marduk-balāṭu was married to fNūptāya, the daughter of Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya/Nūr-Sîn (28 Nbk-­2 Dar) and fIna-Esagila-ramât/Zēria/Nabāya (34 Nbk­15 Dar), which brought about the transfer of parts of the Nūr-Sîn archive; the core of which has not been found. The Egibi archive contains numerous family and property documents, including title deeds, except for the last phase which reinforces it identification as a “dead” archive.

There is a steady increase in the dowries family members received from their wives and gave to their own daughters over the generations, highlighting the family’s economic development from a modest trade in agricultural products, financed through harrānu ventures, to large-scale agricultural undertakings involving the family estates and rented (institutional) land through slave-agents. It seems that Itti-Marduk-balāṭu also took over some of Iddin-Marduk’s business. The family’s patrimony was continuously enlarged through the purchase of (often small) fields (usually turned into date gardens) and plots of urban land. Nabû-ahhē-iddin was the first to have obvious institutional connections: business with the royal family and role as royal judge. This led to an increasing involvement in various forms of tax farming under the first Achaemenid rulers. The absence of temple prebends ownership identifies the Egibis as entrepreneurially oriented urbanites without well-established roots in the traditional temple-oriented establishment.
fields.name: Egibi/Nūr-Sîn

fields.legacy_paraphrase:
Purchase of a garden: A purchases a date garden (kirî gišimmari) for 3 minas and 50 shekels of silver in pieces (šibirtu), together with an additional payment (atru) of 7 shekels of silver, from B1. The sold garden is the (inheritance) share (zittu) the seller divided (zâzu) with his uncle B2. It is located in the district (erṣetu) of the Ninurta Temple inside of Uruk. Its upper side borders on (the property of) the seller’s grandfather B3 and its upper front on (the property of) the seller’s uncle B2. Its lower side borders on the Ninurta Temple and its lower front on the street (sūqu). Neither cardinal directions nor measures are given for the sides of the plot. 11 witnesses and the scribe. Fingernail impressions (ṣupru) of the seller.
 
A = Mušēzib-Marduk/Kiribtu; B1 = Ahhēšāya/Hašdia/Šangû-Ninurta; B2 = Zibāya/Ērešu; B3 = Ērešu//Šangû-Ninurta; Scribe = Šulāya/Ibnāya

fields.paraphrase:
Mušēzib-Marduk/Kiribtu(//Sîn-nāṣir) purchases a share in a date grove in Uruk from Aḫḫēšāya/Ḫašdia//Šangû-Ninurta (A). The other share belongs to Zibāya/Ērešu(//Šangû-Ninurta), uncle of A.

The field is located in the (tp)Quarter of the Ninurta Temple (erṣet bīt Ninurta). It is adjacent to the (tp)Temple of Ninurta, the street and the properties of Ērešu//Šangi-Ninurta and Zibāya/Ērešu(//Šangû-Ninurta).

3 minas and 50 shekels of silver in pieces (šibirtu) are declared (maḫīru nabû) as the purchase price and 7 shekels are added as supplementary payment (atru). The total payment is received. A relinquishes any future claims on behalf of his household.

11 witnesses.

Scribe: Šulāya/Ibnāya.

The document includes the clause concerning fingernail impressions of A, and the tablet is marked with them.

fields.legacy_paraphrase: List of date gardens and their gardeners in Uruk: 7 groups of altogether 47 date gardens with length measures of 40 up to 800 cubits (20 – 400 m). Out of the 47 gardens, 43 gardens are located inside of Uruk and the remaining 4 next to the city wall at the Hariṣu Canal and the Harri Canal.

fields.paraphrase:
Tabulated list of measurements (mišiḫtu) of gardens (kirû) in the limītu-region of Uruk belonging to Ištar and Nanāya. Each garden is allocated to a gardener of … (text: an šu ti) or iššakku-farmer for the granaries (bīt karê).

1. section: 11 plots (qaqqaru) of gardens, measuring 1300 (cubits) in total, located above the city, allocated to Kuzub-ilāni, Šūlāya, Kudurru, Bušēa?, Iqīšāya/Bēl-erība, Bēl-aḫu-iddin/Marduk, Ahu-lurši, Nabû-ušēzib, Bēl-īpuš, Ērešu, Bulluṭu and Iah-nin.

2. section: 7 gardens of the god Gilgameš, measuring 1800 (cubits) in total, allocated to Sappāya?, Kuzub-ilāni, Zēru-ukīn, Ḫaldūa?, Išá-ni-ḫa, Bēl-aḫu-iddin, Bēl-erība.

3. section: 3 gardens, whose front sides are measuring 1100 (cubits) in total, located on the bank of the upper (tp)Royal Canal (nār šarri), allocated to Nabû-aḫu-ēreš/Šalammu, Nabû-aḫḫē-iddin/Idù-[…]-šú, Upāqu/Iun-šá-a.

4. section: 4 gardens, whose front sides are measuring 700 (cubits) in total, located at the Great Gate of Adad. These gardens are recorded (šaṭāru) on the lapis lazuli cylinder seal (kunukku) of Uṣur-amassu. Assurbanipal took them from (thus Janković; Beaulieu: “returned to”) the Urukeans and installed (ṣabātu Š) the gardeners: Tabnēa/Šullumu, Bēl-ušallim/Ṣillāya, Nabû-uṣalli/Nanāya-īpuš, Nabû-aḫu-ēreš/Šalammu.

5. section: 8 gardens, whose front sides are are measuring 1180 (cubits) in total, located below the city, allocated to Bēl-īpuš, Nabû-uṣalli, Aḫu-lurši, Bušēa?, Kudurru, Bēl-usātu, Ḫaḫḫūru, Nādinu.

6. section: 8 gardens, whose front sides are measuring 720 (cubits) in total, belonging to the temple of Ea (or (tp)Bīt-Ea?), allocated to Šumāya, Nabû-ušēzib, Bēl-aḫu-iddin/Marduk, Rīš-ilī, Zēru-ukīn and Kudurru, Kiribtu, Ērešu, Bēl-erība.

7. section: 3 gardens inside the city, and 4 gardens at the ramp (nabalkattu) of the city wall by the bank of the moat (ḫarīṣu) and the (tp)Ditch of Ninurta (ḫarru ša Ninurta), by the city wall, behind the temple of Ninurta facing the countryside, whose front sides are measuring 800 (cubits) in total. At an inspection (masnaqtu) of Uruk Assurbanipal took these gardens from (thus Janković; Beaulieu: “returned to”) the Urukeans and gave them to Ninurta. They are allocated to Ibāya/Erra-suppi (behind the temple of Ninurta, by the city wall), Ubāru, Priest (šangû) of Ninurta (behind the temple of Ninurta), Mūru/Kudurru (by the (tp)Ditch of Urkayītu (ḫarru ša Urkayītu), Nabû-uṣalli/Aḫḫē-erība, Nanāya-īpuš/Aḫḫē-erība, Aḫḫē-lūmur/Nabû-šumu-ibni, Erēbšu/Aḫḫē-erība.

The last section is followed by an isolated mentioning of a plot of Bīšāya/Zākiru neighboring on the New Year festival (building) facing the countryside, whose front side is measuring 300 (cubits). The list ends with the number 2 and a double mentioning of the (tp)Royal Canal (nār šarri).

 

See Beaulieu for collations of l. 1: ˹mi*-ši*-iḫ*-ti* GIŠ.KIRI6.MEŠ…˺, and collations in sections 4 and 7. The text is also discussed by Janković 2013: 338-340.

fields.paraphrase:
Promissory note to pay a debt of silver and barley. Repayment according to the measure of the head of the Egibi family.
B should pay the 1/2 mina of medium quality silver, of which 1/8 is alloy, and the 38 kor of barley which are due from him, to A. Payment should be at the river (ina muhhi nāri) in Til-Gula, in one instalment and according to C’s measure, but it is not specified when it should take place. The place of delivery is further specified at the very end of the obverse, before the list of witnesses: at the lower embankment (ina šapliš kāri). Names of 4 witnesses and the scribe.

A=Marduk-bēlšunu/Arad-Marduk//Šangû-Ea; B=Nabû-ittannu/Nabû-zēru-līšir//Nūr-Papsukkal; C=Marduk-nāṣir-apli (=Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi)
